15-Version-3.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Make-Someone-Smile-Step-16-Version-3.jpg/aid1778315-v4-728px-Make-Someone-Smile-Step-16-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn69@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-02-990_db2db087d1e0c25a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Make-Someone-Smile-Step-17-Version-3.jpg/aid1778315-v4-728px-Make-Someone-Smile-Step-17-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn74@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-00-54-948_b622dba7056121d2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/79/Make-Someone-Smile-Step-18-Version-3.jpg/aid1778315-v4-728px-Make-Someone-Smile-Step-18-Version-3.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Make-Someone-Smile-Step-19-Version-3.jpg/aid1778315-v4-728px-Make-Someone-Smile-Step-19-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn94@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-00-525_d4153e08bc6db02f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e5/Compliments-to-Make-Someone-Smile_sample.png/340px-Compliments-to-Make-Someone-Smile_sample.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn72@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-00-58-573_b4e4b46376f86af0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Random-Acts-of-Kindness-Ideas_sample.png/340px-Random-Acts-of-Kindness-Ideas_sample.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn12@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-02-280_a8e87cb29cb247b2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607673631419},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","title":"How to Glue Hair Extensions","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Glue-in extensions can be a great way to add extra length and volume to your hair, or just to try a new style. If you don’t want to spend the money at a salon, you can purchase extensions, or wefts, and hair bonding glue from a beauty supply store. Then, you can either apply them yourself or ask a friend for help! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Glue-Hair-Extensions&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Glue-Hair-Extensions&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Preparing Your Hair\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Preparing-Your-Hair\">Preparing Your Hair</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Choose extensions made from human hair. Synthetic hair looks unnaturally shiny and won't blend as well into your natural hair color, so it's best to opt for extensions made from 100% human hair. If you can find them, choose extensions that match your hair's natural texture<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>In addition to not looking as good, synthetic hair can actually cause a serious allergic reaction in some people.</li> \n    <li>With extensions, you get what you pay for. You don’t have to spend a fortune, but you’ll get a more natural result if you save up for higher-quality wefts. Human hair extensions will also last longer than synthetic hair extensions.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Select white bonding glue for lighter hair or black glue for dark hair. Your extensions shouldn’t show through your hair, but they’ll blend more naturally if the glue matches the color of the extensions. Hair bonding glue is generally available in either white or black, so opt for white glue if your hair is light blonde to medium brown, or choose black glue if your hair is dark brown to black.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re not sure what type of glue to use, you can ask a sales associate at the same place you buy your extensions.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Trim the extensions to the length you want. Hair extensions come in lengths ranging from . If you do want to cut them yourself, hold each weft up to your head at about the spot where you think it will lay, and look in the mirror to determine the length you want. Mark this spot with your fingers, then trim them with sharp scissors.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re adding the extensions just for extra volume, cut them to the same length as your hair. If you want to add length, your extensions should be cut longer than your natural hair.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Treat your extensions like your own hair if you color them yourself. You can color extensions made from human hair yourself, but it's best to use semi- or demi-permanent colors because they're not as damaging. Lay them flat and apply the hair color, attempting to match the color to the ends of your hair, rather than the roots.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/30/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you want your extensions to look really believable, take them to your hair stylist and have them cut and colored professionally.</li> \n    <li>Do not attempt to dye synthetic hair extensions, as they can be ruined.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wash, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Deep-Condition-Your-Hair\" title=\"Deep Condition Your Hair\">deep condition</a>, and dry your hair before applying the track. The hair bonding glue will adhere better to your hair if it’s free from any oils, so be sure to shampoo your hair thoroughly. In addition, your natural hair will be hidden under the extensions for as long as you have them in. Deep conditioning your hair in advance will help your locks stay nourished and healthy.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Your hair should be completely dry before you apply extensions, so either blow dry it or allow it to air dry.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Gently detangle your hair and the extensions with a comb. You’ll get a more even application if the extensions lie straight on your hair, so be sure both your hair and the weft are free of tangles.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 6 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The extensions are made to be treated like real hair, so although you should be gentle, it’s okay to comb them the same way you would your natural hair.</li> \n    <li>It may help to lay the extensions flat while you’re detangling them.</li> \n    <li>If you have curly hair, it may be easier to detangle your hair before you dry it.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Glue-Hair-Extensions&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Attaching the Extensions\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Attaching-the-Extensions\">Attaching the Extensions</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Section the top part of your hair and clip it up. Use a rat-tail comb to draw a line on either side of your part, from your hairline all the way back to your crown. This should create a rectangular section of hair around your part. Pin this section up with clips or a hair tie.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7c/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you part your hair in the middle, the section should be at the center of your scalp.</li> \n    <li>If you prefer a side part, the section should be off-center.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use your comb to create a U-shaped part above the nape of your neck. Start a little below one of your ears, then follow the natural contour of your head in a U-shape around to your other ear. Leave about <sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make the part as clean as possible, because you don't want stray hairs getting into your glue.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pull the hair above the part up and clip it out of the way. You should be left with a section of hair above the nape of your neck and stretching from ear to ear. This piece of hair will hide your extensions in the back when you pull your hair up into a ponytail.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You’ll need to undo the rest of your hair after you apply the first track, so it’s best to hold the hair up using a banana clip or a similar technique that’s easy to remove.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut the track the width of the part you just created. Hold the weft against your scalp about away from your hairline, then stretch it to the other side to away from your hairline. Use your thumb to mark the place where your extension should end as you pull the weft away from your head.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Cut the weft with scissors, then hold the extension piece up to double-check the width.</li> \n    <li>You want to leave the extensions at least from your hairline because the piece of hair that’s left will hide the extensions if you pull your hair back.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Lay the track flat on a table and apply a line of glue all the way down. The side of the track with the hair attached should be face-down. Apply the glue in small increments until the entire track is covered.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>There should be enough glue to coat the weft but not drip off.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Blow dry the glue on high or medium for several seconds. This will help the glue become tacky so it will adhere to your hair. If the glue is too wet when you apply the extension, the glue will drip down the strands of hair, causing a messier application.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-12.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Touch the glue to make sure it's neither runny nor dry. It should be about 60-70% dry when you’re finished drying it.</li> \n    <li>Some hair stylists will also apply a strong hold hairspray at this stage and then blow dry your hair.</li> \n    <li>If you're using synthetic hair, make sure your blowdryer is on the cool setting.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Press the extension onto your hair about from the root. The line of the track should run slightly below the part you made near the nape of your neck. Do not apply glue on your scalp. <sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-13.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you apply the extension directly to your scalp, it can stunt the growth of your hair and lead to hair damage.</li> \n    <li>Remember to leave the hair at least away from your hairline.</li> \n    <li>If you find that your extension wasn’t cut long enough, just snip a little piece and apply it using the same method.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Blow dry the track again for another 30-60 seconds. This will finish drying the glue so the extension will stay attached to your hair. To check whether the glue is dry, gently tug on the extensions. If they move, continue drying them.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-14.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you opted for synthetic extensions, you may want to use the cool setting on your hair dryer.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Draw a part above the first one and apply another track. The width of your sections can vary based on how thick you want your extensions to be. If you’re primarily hoping to add volume, space them so they’re a little closer.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-15.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use the same technique to apply the second extension as you did the first.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Continue adding extensions this way until you reach your ears. Once your part falls above your ears, your U-shape will start near your temple, then will reach back towards your crown and circle around towards your other temple.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-16.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You’ll still follow the same application technique, but your extensions will be a little longer since they’re reaching further around.</li> \n    <li>This wide U-shape will mimic the natural fall of your hair and should make the finished result look more natural.</li> \n    <li>Place your last extension around the rectangular shape you made at the beginning of the process.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Unclip the top section of hair and gently comb it down. This top section of your hair should completely hide your extensions, so you’re ready to enjoy your glamorous new look!<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-17.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 17.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d1/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-17.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-17.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When you're combing out your hair, be sure not to push the comb into your extensions. Gently comb just along the surface of the hair to smooth it out.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Glue-Hair-Extensions&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Caring for Your Extensions\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Caring-for-Your-Extensions\">Caring for Your Extensions</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Treat your extensions the way you would your real hair. Shampooing your extensions can loosen them up, so you may want to hold off on shampooing your hair until you are ready for the extensions to come out. You should brush or comb them regularly, but be careful when you’re combing your hair. Do not place the comb directly onto the glue or you may pull out your extensions, and maybe even some of your own hair.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 18 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can heat style extensions made from real hair, although you should limit how much you do so, or your extensions may start to look damaged and messy.</li> \n    <li>Just like with your regular hair, you can spray your extensions with a heat protectant to help prevent damage due to styling.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Keep oil away from your scalp. Don’t apply conditioner directly on your roots, and avoid putting hair oil near your extensions. Oil will dissolve the glue, making your extensions fall out before you’re ready.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-19.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 19.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-19.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-19.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Don't neglect your real hair. Since your natural hair is hidden by your weave, it can be easy to forget about it. However, your hair may become matted or break off if you don't take care of it. Make sure to wash, condition, and detangle your real hair while you’re caring for your extensions.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-20-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 20 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-20-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To detangle your real hair, gently lift the extension and comb out the shorter pieces of your own hair.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Apply an oil-based solvent when you want to take out the extensions. Saturate your scalp and the bonded wefts thoroughly with scalp oil or silicone spray so the glue completely softens. You can then gently slide the wefts off of your real hair. If there is any glue residue left on your hair and scalp, apply the solvent to a fine-toothed comb and use it to gently remove the glue.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-21-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 21 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-21-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-21-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You should usually take out your extensions after about 3 weeks, but if you’re experiencing scalp pain or excess shedding, take them out sooner.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wait a week or two before you apply new extensions. Overuse of extensions can cause loss of hair due to the pulling and extra weight on the hair strand. Give your hair a break once you take out the extensions.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-22.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Glue Hair Extensions Step 22.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-22.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-22.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Glue-Hair-Extensions&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Glue-in extensions work best on thick or coarse hair. If your hair is very thin, you may prefer another method.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Glue-Hair-Extensions&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Do not apply glue directly to your scalp.</li> \n  <li>Do not use any glue other than hair bonding glue to attach your extensions.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Glue-Hair-Extensions&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Glue-Hair-Extensions&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Glue-Hair-Extensions#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a -7-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn14@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-00-57-756_14dca5bfa88b9072.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn58@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-57-116_61e017321fc4b065.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn13@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-55-494_c8987f231c5f8ca6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn76@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-01-05-579_ecc7499f9a102d02.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn41@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-55-696_81bc06003d3c8305.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-12.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn17@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-55-523_d55198bee35f5160.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-13.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn26@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-04-864_15f8679f949142cd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-14.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-14.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-15.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn21@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-00-55-525_ba8e4b9dd608b1b2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-16.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-16.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn83@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-01-914_18d5eefadff9c653.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d1/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-17.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-17.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn26@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-08-036_8744546a2284f818.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-18-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn9@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-03-476_07c0c5ad4bb185db.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-19.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-19.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn38@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-05-200_9c770fae32e55688.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-20-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn97@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-00-54-562_04334e5075887aa7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-21-Version-2.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-21-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn21@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-00-56-727_278cbc8ce9bb793c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-22.jpg/aid1378451-v4-728px-Glue-Hair-Extensions-Step-22.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn21@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-57-998_b7fcf43114cb8670.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607673631431},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","title":"How to Block Mobile Phone Spam","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Just when you think you've got <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Get-Rid-of-Junk-Mail\" title=\"Get Rid of Junk Mail\">junk mail</a> and <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stop-Spam\" title=\"Stop Spam\">e-mail spam</a> under control, you might start getting unsolicited text messages on your mobile phone. This can be especially irritating because you normally can't delete a text message without opening it. Depending on your wireless plan, you may get charged for text messages. In some cases, they may contain malware and viruses. This wikiHow teaches you how to block spam text messages on your email. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <ol>\n  <li>Do not reply to spam messages. If you receive a spam text messages that you did not ask for, it's important that you do not reply to it. Both legitimate and illegitimate Robo-text messages will often contain the option to text \"STOP\" to be removed from the distribution list. If the text message comes from a scammer, this will only confirm that your number is valid. Then they will likely sell your number to other scammers, which can result in more spam. Do not reply to any unwanted text message unless you know where it originates from.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Apologize-For-Cheating-on-Your-Partner-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Apologize For Cheating on Your Partner Step 16 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Apologize-For-Cheating-on-Your-Partner-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid386933-v4-728px-Apologize-For-Cheating-on-Your-Partner-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Legitimate marketing messages will generally contain a name, contact info, and the name of the organization they are from.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>If you're not sure if a call or text message is from a legitimate business, hang up and call the business directly on their official phone number.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Do not open any links or attachments. If you receive a spam text message or email with an attachment or a link to a website, do not open it. It may contain malware or spyware that can infect your phone.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-2-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Block Mobile Phone Spam Step 2 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/df/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-2-Version-4.jpg/aid386933-v4-728px-Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-2-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Block repeat numbers on your phone. If you are repeatedly receiving spam from the same number, you can try to block the spam directly on your phone. The problem is that many scammers use spoof numbers that frequently change. So even if you block one spam number, you may continue to receive spam from other numbers. Still, it doesn't hurt to try. Use the following steps to block spam numbers:\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-3-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Block Mobile Phone Spam Step 3 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d6/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-3-Version-4.jpg/aid386933-v4-728px-Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-3-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li><b>iPhone:</b><sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup> \n     <ul>\n      <li>Tap a message from the spammer you want to block.</li> \n      <li>Tap the profile image above the spammer's number.</li> \n      <li>Tap the <b>Info</b> tab.</li> \n      <li>Tap <b>Block this caller</b>.</li>\n     </ul></li> \n    <li><b>Android:</b> \n     <ul>\n      <li>Tap a message from the spammer you want to block.</li> \n      <li>Tap the icon with three dots (<b>⋮</b>) in the upper-right corner.</li> \n      <li>Tap <b>Block [number]</b>.</li> \n      <li>Tap <b>Block</b>.</li>\n     </ul></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Forward spam messages to (SPAM) to report them. You can easily report spam text messages to your mobile service provider by forwarding or sending a copy of the spam message to 7726 (SPAM). Make sure the text message includes the sender's number. This works with Verizon Wireless, AT&amp;T, Sprint, and T-Mobile. You will not receive any charges for reporting spam messages.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-4-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Block Mobile Phone Spam Step 4 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-4-Version-4.jpg/aid386933-v4-728px-Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-4-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Enable Spam Protection (Android Only). Some Android phones allow you to enable spam protection to block spam text messages or calls. This feature is not available on all Android phones. Use the following steps to enable Spam Protection on an Android phone:\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-5-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Block Mobile Phone Spam Step 5 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-5-Version-5.jpg/aid386933-v4-728px-Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-5-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Open the <b>Messages</b> app.</li> \n    <li>Tap the icon with three dots (<b>⋮</b>) in the upper-right corner.</li> \n    <li>Tap <b>Settings</b>.</li> \n    <li>Tap <b>Advanced</b> or <b>More Settings</b>.</li> \n    <li>Tap the toggle switch to enable or disable Spam Protection.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>See if your mobile carrier offers a call-blocking service. Many service providers offer call-blocking services where they can use a database of known spam numbers to block you from receiving calls. These can also be useful at blocking text messages. Dial \"611\" on your phone to contact your mobile carrier and inquire about call and message blocking services. In some cases, these services may cost extra.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-6-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Block Mobile Phone Spam Step 6 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-6-Version-4.jpg/aid386933-v4-728px-Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-6-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Use a third-party app to block spam messages. If neither your phone nor carrier has robust spam protection, you can use third-party apps to block spam calls and text messages, but they generally have a subscription fee. Nomorobo ($1.99 per month or $19.99 per year) can block spam calls on Android and spam calls and text messages on iPhone. Robokiller ($3.99 per month or $29.99 per year) can block spam calls and text messages on both Android and iPhone. Hiya is a free call-blocker app that can block spam calls, but not text messages. These apps are available from the Google Play Store on Android or App Store on iPhone.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-7-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Block Mobile Phone Spam Step 7 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-7-Version-4.jpg/aid386933-v4-728px-Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-7-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Android users will need to install Robokiller and use it as their default caller ID and spam app. Open Robokiller and tap the <b>Settings</b> tab. Then tap the toggle switch next to \"SMS Spam Recognition\" to be notified about unwanted text messages.</li> \n    <li>iPhone users will need to install Robokiller or Nomorobo. Open the Settings app on your phone and tap <b>Messages</b>. Tap <b>Unknown &amp; Spam</b>. Then tap the toggle switch next to Nomorobo or Robokiller. This will enable those apps to block spam on your iPhone.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Register your phone number on the Do Not Call list. Once your number is registered with the Do Not Call registry, telemarketers are required to remove your phone number from their call list and stop calling within 31 days. Regardless of whether or not you are on the Do Not Call list, it is illegal to send text messages to a mobile phone using an auto dialer without consent.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup> You can register for the Do Not Call list at <b><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.donotcall.gov/\">https://www.donotcall.gov/</a></b>.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Block Mobile Phone Spam Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/97/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid386933-v4-728px-Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You may still receive calls and text from charities, political groups, debt collectors, and surveys.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Report unwanted calls and texts to the FCC. If you continue receiving spam calls and text, especially after you are registered on the Do Not Call list, you can file a consumer complaint with the FCC. You can file a complaint with the FCC at <b><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://consumercomplaints.fcc.gov/hc/en-us\">https://consumercomplaints.fcc.gov/hc/en-us</a></b>.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Block Mobile Phone Spam Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid386933-v4-728px-Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stop-Spam\" title=\"Stop Spam\">Stop Spam</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stop-Male-Enhancement-Spam-on-Outlook-or-Vista-Mail\" title=\"Stop Male Enhancement Spam on Outlook or Vista Mail\">Stop Male Enhancement Spam on Outlook or Vista Mail</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Block-Porn-on-Android\" title=\"Block Porn on Android\">Block Porn on Android</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Block-Android-Text-Messages\" title=\"Block Android Text Messages\">Block Android Text Messages</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Respond-to-Incoming-Calls-with-a-Message-on-an-iPhone\" title=\"Respond to Incoming Calls with a Message on an iPhone\">Respond to Incoming Calls with a Message on an iPhone</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Block-a-Number-on-Blackberry\" title=\"Block a Number on Blackberry\">Block a Number on Blackberry</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Block-a-Number-on-Verizon\" title=\"Block a Number on Verizon\">Block a Number on Verizon</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Block-Mobile-Phone-Spam#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.moneysavingexpert.com/mobiles/stop-spam-texts/\">https://www.moneysavingexpert.com/mobiles/stop-spam-texts/</a></span> </li> \n   <li
