</li> \n   <li id=\"_note-28\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Gym-Equipment#_ref-28\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.self.com/story/guide-to-navigating-free-weights-at-the-gym?verso=true\">https://www.self.com/story/guide-to-navigating-free-weights-at-the-gym?verso=true</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-29\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Gym-Equipment#_ref-29\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/better/lifestyle/new-gym-use-these-strategies-make-most-your-workouts-ncna963666\">https://www.nbcnews.com/better/lifestyle/new-gym-use-these-strategies-make-most-your-workouts-ncna963666</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-30\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Gym-Equipment#_ref-30\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6269393/\">https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6269393/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-31\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Gym-Equipment#_ref-31\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.shape.com.sg/fitness/correct-use-gym-equipment/\">https://www.shape.com.sg/fitness/correct-use-gym-equipment/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-32\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Gym-Equipment#_ref-32\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/better/lifestyle/new-gym-use-these-strategies-make-most-your-workouts-ncna963666\">https://www.nbcnews.com/better/lifestyle/new-gym-use-these-strategies-make-most-your-workouts-ncna963666</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 07 Dec 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"976eee52182a9660077a5565549ee2af","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn75@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-31-696_0f95a5d330a35279.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":59638,"destBytes":36796,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn75@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-31-696_0f95a5d330a35279.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn89@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-59-717_596c9c5c69a37bcf.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/79/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn7@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-05-994_c9a9b7aa22657c24.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn46@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-01-01-346_afd0b3872186fd64.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn38@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-02-013_529aef1efce5122f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn77@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-57-399_0570ef325022aed1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/60/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn98@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-00-57-512_3ab65779baa60785.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn80@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-04-380_9d41579eccd1df36.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn2@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-00-59-126_509e2c07ce5b0017.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-13-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn59@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-09-490_92403abaf3de4146.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2e/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-14-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn40@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-09-173_b586aff42c4246e3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-15-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn6@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-10-159_58cfc857f119ba90.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-16-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn78@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-00-399_c7aaf0f0533d154e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-17-Version-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-18-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn54@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-02-782_71c0b4a530cda763.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-19-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn88@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-06-904_e283449631c76038.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-20-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn87@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-02-045_c7f93990e282c1a8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-21.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-21.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn64@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-00-58-499_f5cea3546929a9f1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d6/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-22.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-22.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-23.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-23.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn83@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-01-04-376_25a83cd5bfcc80bd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-24.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-24.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn72@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-01-07-568_6d7c171e4832e561.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-25.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-25.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn9@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-00-54-384_89aa10b766b4640d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-26.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-26.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn41@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-00-58-250_7ed7ac44c8bb11fe.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-27.jpg/aid1134174-v4-728px-Use-Gym-Equipment-Step-27.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn83@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-00-476_f4892fd20e212b30.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607673631433},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","title":"How to Clean Skateboard Wheels","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>If your skateboard is feeling kind of sticky as you ride it, it might be time to give your wheels a clean. Your wheels and bearings can get blocked up with dirt and rocks, which can lead to a not-so-smooth feel. Luckily, cleaning your wheels and bearings is relatively easy, and only requires some disassembling and a little bit of cleaning solution. Once your bearings and wheels are ridden from built up dirt, you’ll be cruising around in no time. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Skateboard-Wheels&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Skateboard-Wheels&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Wheels\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Wheels\">Wheels</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Remove the wheels from the axle using a wrench. Turn the skateboard over so it is resting on the deck, with the wheels facing up. Use a socket wrench to twist and remove the axle nuts on the outer sides of the skateboard wheels, then set them aside.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep all wheel materials (nuts, washers, etc.) together in one place so you can easily find and attach them later. You’ll need every piece you take off, so don’t lose them!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pry the bearings out of the wheels with the truck axle. Grab one wheel and place the center against the metal rod that it was attached to (this is called the truck axle). Use the rod to pop the bearing out of the wheel, kind of like you’d use a bottle opener on a bottle top. Use the same prying technique for all 4 of your wheels, and keep the bearings in one spot so you don’t lose track of them.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep the wheel bearings and the wheels separate from each other so they’re easier to clean.</li> \n    <li>If you can’t manage to remove the bearings in this way, try using a screwdriver to pry out the bearings. Simply hold on to the sides of the wheel out in front of you, insert the tip of the screwdriver in the front of the wheel, and pull the screwdriver to the side to release the bearing.</li> \n    <li>When you remove the bearings from the wheels, a bearing spacer will fall out from the center of the wheel. Keep this in a safe place so you can reassemble the wheel and bearings later.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wipe off the surface of your wheels with a rag to clean off dirt and rocks. Use your fingers to loosen any rocks or gravel, then use your rag to really scrub hard. If there’s any super dirty areas that need a lot of scrubbing, grab a toothbrush and use that instead.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don’t worry if you can’t get your wheels sparkly clean just yet—this is just the first step!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Soak the wheels in soapy water for 10 minutes. Fill a bucket or your sink with about of warm water and of dish soap. Stir the mixture up until it’s sudsy, then submerge your wheels and let them sit for about 10 minutes.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Just soak the wheels, not the bearings! Soaking your bearings in water can make them rust.</li> \n    <li>The warm water will help to loosen any stuck-on dirt and grime.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wipe down the wheels with a rag or a toothbrush. Take your wheels out of the soapy water and give them a good scrub down. Here’s where you can work super hard to make sure they look sparkly and clean.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/df/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure you’re wiping down the inside of the wheels as well as the outside. Small rocks and dirt can get trapped in any nook and cranny.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Dry the wheels off with a clean rag. Grab a separate rag and wipe your wheels off until they’re mostly dry. You can set them aside to air dry the rest of the way while you work on your bearings.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 6 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/30/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure your wheels are super dry before you reassemble your skateboard so you don’t slip and fall while riding.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Skateboard-Wheels&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Bearings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Bearings\">Bearings</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Pop the bearing shields off with a razor blade. Position your razor blade in between the bearing shield and the edge of the bearing. Gently push the blade down to pop the shield off the bearing and separate the 2 pieces.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If a razor blade doesn't work, try a safety pin or a screwdriver instead.</li> \n    <li>Be very gentle as you take the shield off! You can damage the thin material if you’re too rough.</li> \n    <li>Some bearings only have one shield, while others have shields on both sides.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pour of solvent into a bowl. To clean your bearings, you can use a cleaning solvent, like rubbing alcohol or mineral spirits. If you’d like something a little less harsh, you can use a liquid citrus cleaner. Pour your solvent of choice into a bowl or plastic container to get it ready for your bearings.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 8 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can find bearing cleaning kits at most skateboard shops, but they’re often more expensive than just buying the solvent yourself.</li> \n    <li>If you are using a harsh solvent, put on gloves to protect your skin before you start.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Soak the bearings in the solution for 5 minutes. Carefully drop all of your bearings into your solution, making sure they’re fully submerged. Swirl them around in your container a little bit so all the sides get fully covered, then leave them to soak for about 5 minutes.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Leaving your bearings to soak for too long can damage them, so make sure you take them out right away.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Tap each bearing onto a paper towel to get the solvent off. Put on your gloves again and carefully grab all your bearings out of the cleaning solution. One by one, tap the bearings onto a clean paper towel with the exposed side down to get the excess solvent out and dry the bearings off.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If there’s still solvent in the bearings, use a toothbrush to scrub the insides.</li> \n    <li>Don’t spin the bearings to get the solvent out—this could splash harsh chemicals into your eyes or face.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drop 1 to 2 drops of oil into the bearings. You can use skateboard oils, sewing machine oils, or electronic oils. Add 2 to 3 drops to the exposed side of each bearing, then spin it to make sure all the bearing balls are evenly coated. Wipe off any excess with a paper towel to clean up.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Too much lubricant can clog up the bearing rather than making it move smoothly. When in doubt, the less lubricant the better.</li> \n    <li>Do not use thick oils as a lubricant on your bearings. Avoid lubricants like olive oil, vegetable oil, or motor oil, as they can clog up your board.</li> \n    <li>Something like WD-40 will lubricate your wheels for a minute or two, but the bearings will quickly dry out.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Skateboard-Wheels&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Reassembly\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reassembly\">Reassembly</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Snap the bearing shields back into place. Grab your bearing shield (remember those thin pieces of rubber?) and use your thumbs to snap it onto the exposed side of your bearing. This shouldn’t take much effort, so you can assemble your bearings fairly quickly.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/55/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-12.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The shields help trap the lubricant on the inside of the bearing to keep them smooth.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Insert the bearings back into the wheels. Push one bearing into a wheel, then use your fingers to snap it into place. Turn the wheel over and insert the bearing divider, then snap the other bearing into place.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-13.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This is why it’s important to keep all the hardware in one spot!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Attach the wheels to your truck axle with the axle nut. Slide each wheel onto the truck axle that’s attached to your skateboard, then put the axle nut back on the outside of each wheel. Use your socket wrench to tighten the nut in place, then give your wheels a spin!<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Skateboard Wheels Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-14.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Be careful not to overtighten the nut. If you can’t spin your wheels, loosen it up again with your wrench.</li> \n    <li>Your wheels should feel smoother without any sticky grinding as you ride.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Skateboard-Wheels&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Skateboard-Wheels&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Use a cup to hold all your bolts and small objects in one place.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Skateboard-Wheels&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Never use bleach on your wheels, as it can dry out the rubber in the wheels and cause them to weaken.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Skateboard-Wheels&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Socket wrench or skate tool</li> \n  <li>Clean rags</li> \n  <li>Paper towels</li> \n  <li>Solvent</li> \n  <li>Bowl</li> \n  <li>Dish soap</li> \n  <li>Thin lubricant</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Skateboard-Wheels&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Replace-Skateboard-Bearings\" title=\"Replace Skateboard Bearings\">Replace Skateboard Bearings</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Skateboard-Bearings\" title=\"Clean Skateboard Bearings\">Clean Skateboard Bearings</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Skateboard-Wheels&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Dec 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"6a5e52bcd71d727fad2c39006500d20f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn15@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-31-725_a3fc94c73cf06105.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":43678,"destBytes":20074,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn15@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-31-725_a3fc94c73cf06105.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn25@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-02-613_e03ffd81ea28154f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn61@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-10-564_822dd71b1ed18f08.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn1@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-00-54-434_4b49a46f62896b05.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/df/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn2@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-08-030_61884d7a20b4576e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/30/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn65@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-01-976_0202e02b718cc4ed.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn33@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-58-120_e2ff2e3f85de9b43.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-8-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn96@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-05-800_a1b793e74e0e2084.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn57@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-00-314_83695f672444c202.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn33@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-00-59-939_82d4d19e08c587f0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn80@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-06-916_740cf95585b2a951.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/55/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-12.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn65@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-00-283_f04f68f4f141887c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-13.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn33@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-00-55-579_e3b06dae18d469ea.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-14.jpg/aid1015808-v4-728px-Clean-Skateboard-Wheels-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn70@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-00-57-107_1fc400b922766bcc.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607673631410},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","title":"How to Make Bedspreads","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>If you're tired of searching for a bedspread that matches your style, sew your own unique spread. Bedspreads are great projects for sewers with a little experience since you can truly customize the look. All you need is fabric, batting, a sewing machine, and about an hour to create a hand-sewn bedspread. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bedspreads&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bedspreads&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Cutting the Materials\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cutting-the-Materials\">Cutting the Materials</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Buy stylish fabric to fit the measurements of your bed. Although you can find narrower bolts, choose a comfortable fabric that's at least wide regardless of the bedspread size. For an easy spread, buy 2 sets of flat sheets that fit your bed. Choose a fabric that you can machine wash and dry. Cotton, wool, or acrylic blends are all popular fabrics for bedspreads and they wear well. To use fabric from the bolt, buy:<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Make-Bedspreads-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Twin and full: for the top and for the bottom</li> \n    <li>Queen: for the top and for the bottom</li> \n    <li>King: for the top and for the bottom</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut 2 or 3 panels of fabric for each side of the bedspread. Since your fabric bolt is wide, sew 2 panels together for each side of a twin or full-size bedspread. For a queen or king, use 3 horizontal panels for each side.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Make-Bedspreads-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Cut the panels long for twin or full-sized bedspreads.</li> \n    <li>Make each panel long for queen or king-sized bedspreads.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Line up the panels and use fusible bonding tape to iron them together. If you're making a twin or full-sized spread, place 2 of the long panels next to each other pattern-side up so the panels line up. For a queen or twin-sized spread, lay 3 of the panels together pattern-side up so the long sides touch. Then, lay a strip of fusible bonding tape along 1 side of each panel where it touches the other panel. Overlap the other panel and iron it so they fuse together.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Make-Bedspreads-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don't want raw edges showing, tuck the side of the top panel under by before you iron it onto the other panel.</li> \n    <li>If you're using fabric with a pattern, line up the pattern before you join the panels.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Sew the top fabric panels together. Take the panel pieces to your sewing machine and arrange them so the pattern faces down. Zigzag stitch down the side of the panels where you fused them with the bonding tape. Repeat this for the other panel if you're making a queen or king-sized bedspread.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/09/Make-Bedspreads-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use thread that matches the color of your fabric so it doesn't stand out.</li> \n    <li>If you're using thick fabric, trim the excess fabric from the seam so your bedspread isn't bulky.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut the fabric piece to fit the size of your bed. Spread the assembled fabric flat and get out fabric chalk and a yardstick. Mark the dimensions on the fabric and use scissors to cut out the top fabric piece. Cut the piece:<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Make-Bedspreads-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Twin:</li> \n    <li>Full:</li> \n    <li>Queen:</li> \n    <li>King:</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Sew the bottom panels together to make the underside of the bedspread. Set aside the top piece while you repeat the steps using the fabric that you chose for the bottom of the bedspread. Arrange 2 or 3 panel pieces pattern-side up and fuse them together. Then, make straight stitches down the sides of the panels to join them as you did for the top fabric piece.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/Make-Bedspreads-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Once you've finished preparing the top and bottom fabric pieces, you'll just need to get out enough batting for filling the comforter.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Unroll quilt batting and cut it to the same size as the bedspread. Buy a package of quilt batting according to your bed size and unroll it on your work surface. Spread 1 of your bedspread fabric pieces on the batting and cut the excess batting from the sides so the batting is the same size as the fabric. For a warmer blanket, use more than 1 layer of batting.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/48/Make-Bedspreads-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can buy batting made from cotton, polyester, or bamboo, for instance. Cotton and bamboo are great natural choices, while polyester is easy to find and inexpensive. Wool batting is a good choice if you want a very warm bedspread.</li> \n    <li>Keep in mind that more layers are more likely to shift around so it's important to sew over the blanket to keep the batting in place.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bedspreads&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Sewing a Basic Bedspread\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Sewing-a-Basic-Bedspread\">Sewing a Basic Bedspread</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Stack the batting on the 2 fabric pieces and pin the sides in place. Lay the batting piece flat on your work surface and put the top bedspread piece directly on it with the pattern facing up. Line up the sides with the batting. Then, place the bottom bedspread piece on top so the pattern faces down and line up the sides. Insert sewing pins along the edges of the bedspread so the pins go through all 3 layers.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Make-Bedspreads-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Put the sewing pins about every along the sides.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Sew straight stitches around 3 sides of the bedspread. Take the bedspread to the sewing machine and sew from the raw edge. Make straight stitches down the long side, 1 short end, and up the other long side.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a6/Make-Bedspreads-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It's important to leave 1 of the short ends open so you can turn the bedspread right-side out.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Turn the bedspread right-side out and pin the raw edge closed. Reach into the bedspread and grab hold of the fabric. Flip it out so the batting is in the middle and the fashion fabric encloses it. Then, smooth out the bedspread so the batting is even and tuck the raw edges under by . Insert sewing pins every along the last side.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/09/Make-Bedspreads-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Before you pin the edge of the spread, push into the corners with your fingers or a knitting needle to give them sharp definition.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Top stitch around the entire bedspread so the edges lay flat. Start sewing along the unfinished edge that you just pinned and make straight stitches that are away from the edge. Keep topstitching around the other sides that you already finished and keep close to the edge to stabilize it.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Make-Bedspreads-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Remember to remove sewing pins as you work so you don't damage your sewing machine.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stitch across the bedspread if you want to secure the batting. Batting can clump a little after you wash and dry the bedspread a few times. To keep it in place, straight stitch across the bedspread in any design you like. To make a simple grid, sew 3 or 4 straight lines across the length of the bedspread. Leave an equal amount of space between each line. Then, make 5 or 6 straight lines across the short side of the spread with equal space between them.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Make-Bedspreads-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you'd like the topstitching to stand out instead of blend in, use a different color of thread. For example, if you have a cream-colored bedspread, use burgundy or cornflower blue thread that compliments the fabric.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Attach a ruffle to the ends and sides of your bedspread for a frilled look. Buy a dust ruffle that fits your bed and cut away the flat smooth part that covers the top of the bed. Lay the assembled bedspread so the back faces up and line up the raw edges of the ruffle with the sides of the spread so the ruffles extend out. Then, use a zigzag stitch to sew the ruffle to the sides of the bedspread.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Make-Bedspreads-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You could also <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Dust-Ruffle\" title=\"Make a Dust Ruffle\">make your own ruffled strips</a> so they're as long as you like.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut a slit in each corner to make a fitted split corner bedspread. Bedspreads usually shift around a little, but if you want yours to stay in place, make it hug the corners of your bed. Lay your assembled bedspread on the bed so the sides fall evenly and cut a diagonal line from a bottom corner up to the top of the mattress. Then, tuck the raw edges under by and <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Hem\" title=\"Hem\">hem</a> them before repeating this for each corner of the spread.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bedspreads#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bedspreads-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bedspreads Step 14 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Make-Bedspreads-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don't want to eyeball the cutting, trace the line with fabric chalk so you have a guideline.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bedspreads&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you're concerned that the fabric will shrink, wash and dry it before sewing the bedspread.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bedspreads&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Fabric</li> \n  <li>Fusible bonding tape</li> \n  <li>Quilt batting</li> \n  <li>Scissors</li> \n  <li>Ruler</li> \n  <li>Sewing machine</li> \n  <li>Sewing pins</li> \n  <li>Iron and ironing board</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bedspreads&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Find-a-Theme-to-Decorate-a-Small-Bedroom\" title=\"Find a Theme to Decorate a Small Bedroom\">Find a Theme to Decorate a Small Bedroom</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Bring-Color-Into-Your-Home\" title=\"Bring Color Into Your Home\">Bring Color Into Your Home</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Hand-Sew-a-Quilt\" title=\"Hand Sew a Quilt\">Hand Sew a Quilt</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a
