\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 09 Dec 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Make-Bedspreads-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"b7eaca79d8147035dcdeb851be0a2274","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn44@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-32-187_9ed133509f29cc3f.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":83500,"destBytes":55698,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Make-Bedspreads-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn44@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-32-187_9ed133509f29cc3f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Make-Bedspreads-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn45@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-08-270_2951b9d3ef9861e0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Make-Bedspreads-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn75@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-01-07-612_cd126054ddcae5c9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/09/Make-Bedspreads-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn52@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-06-623_b6f2851faa3a8299.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Make-Bedspreads-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn71@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-06-678_2d26647ef6bdd235.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/Make-Bedspreads-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn54@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-04-076_dad950f295ad4aa9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/48/Make-Bedspreads-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn47@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-00-58-275_b94165a54b54c9a1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Make-Bedspreads-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn62@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-05-374_f7dc45043ed0f578.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a6/Make-Bedspreads-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn17@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-56-581_8d95ecec1bbe0960.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/09/Make-Bedspreads-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn69@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-01-01-596_fbecb998f70843c4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Make-Bedspreads-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn100@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-07-065_b36433594195be6f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Make-Bedspreads-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn99@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-05-833_d9e90384e1897f6c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Make-Bedspreads-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-13-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn77@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-01-03-267_4c21879241f8c253.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Make-Bedspreads-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid1355610-v4-728px-Make-Bedspreads-Step-14-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn67@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-06-712_7af7174b750f3b1c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607673631402},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","title":"How to Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Carrying a growing baby in the womb can bring about a lot of uncomfortable physical pains and irritations. Knowing how to alleviate many of these pains can make this part of the pregnancy process less uncomfortable, and help make your pregnancy as successful as possible. If you’re experiencing any severe symptoms, talk to your doctor or your midwife right away. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Nausea and Vomiting\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Nausea-and-Vomiting\">Nausea and Vomiting</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Go for small, frequent meals to avoid overloading your system. Large, heavy meals can make you feel nauseous or even throw up. Instead, go for 4 to 5 light snacks throughout the day to keep your stomach settled without overpowering it.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Fresh fruit, yogurt, granola bars, and crackers are all great foods to snack on throughout the day.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Get out of bed slowly to avoid aggravating your stomach. If you’re experiencing morning sickness, you need to be extra careful as you get out of bed. Spend about 20 minutes from the time you wake up to the time you get out of bed to gradually ease yourself into a sitting position.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Going from lying down to sitting up super quickly can upset your stomach, leading to nausea and vomiting.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Eat carb and protein-heavy foods that are easy to digest. Carbs aren’t too difficult for your body to break down, and they give you a quick burst of energy. Protein is great for your body, and you can find it without a lot of heavy grease. Go for foods like bread, crackers, oats, fruit, turkey, chicken, eggs, and almonds.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Rich, greasy foods that are oil-heavy can make you feel sick.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drink carbonated drinks to help settle your stomach. Soda water and sparkling water are nice light flavors that won’t upset your stomach. You could also go for ginger ale or chamomile tea to help with nausea. Try to drink your liquids separate from your meals to avoid overloading your stomach.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try to avoid sugary sodas, since they can overload your stomach and make you feel worse.</li> \n    <li>Being dehydrated can make you nauseous, so it’s important to drink as many liquids as possible.</li> \n    <li>Fresh ginger can also help you alleviate your nausea.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Take your prenatal vitamins as directed. Some studies show that vitamin B6 can help alleviate nausea. Most prenatal vitamins include this already, but if you think you need more, talk to your doctor about increasing your dose. Always drink a full glass of water with your vitamins, and take it during a meal if it upsets your stomach.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The maximum amount of vitamin B6 you can take per day is 100 mg. If you go over that, you could make yourself feel sick.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wait 1 hour after eating before lying down to avoid heartburn. If you’re experiencing acid reflux or heartburn, try to eat your meals 1 hour before bed. That way, your stomach has time to digest them before shifting positions.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you deal with frequent heartburn, talk to your doctor before taking antacids. Some of them aren’t good for people who are pregnant.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wear a sea sickness wristband to alleviate your nausea. Sea sickness bands add a little bit of pressure to the pressure point in your wrist, which can help to relieve nausea. Buy one of these bands from a pharmacy near you to try it out.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>These bands don’t work for everyone, so you should try them in conjunction with other remedies.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Constipation and Frequent Urination\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Constipation-and-Frequent-Urination\">Constipation and Frequent Urination</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Eat more fiber to regulate your bowel movements. Fiber-heavy foods can help soften your stool naturally. Go for beans, apples, lentils, prunes, or whole grains to keep your bowel movements regular.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When you have a bowel movement, don't strain, as that can lead to hemorrhoids. Try propping your feet on a low stool to make it easier to go, which can help reduce how much you need to strain.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Eat prunes or figs as a natural laxative. Prunes, prune juice, and figs all help soften your stool and can relieve constipation naturally. Try eating or drinking these fruits throughout the day to keep your bowel movements regular.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-9.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Natural laxatives are a good choice, since many doctors recommend staying away from over the counter laxatives while pregnant.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drink a lot of fluids to stay hydrated. If you’re dehydrated, your stool will probably be harder, which can lead to constipation. Try to drink about 8 glasses of water per day to keep your bowel movements flowing.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-10.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re already dealing with excessive urination, it can seem counterintuitive to add more liquids to your diet. However, staying hydrated is super important, and you should never limit your intake just to avoid going pee.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Do some gentle exercise to get your bowels moving. Walking, stretching, and even yoga can help move your bowel movement lower. If you feel constipated, try doing a few simple exercises until you feel the need to go.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-11.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Only exercise if you’re feeling up to it and your doctor gives you the okay.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Empty your bladder completely to avoid constant trips to the bathroom. When you do go pee, make sure you sit on the toilet until every last drop comes out. If there’s still urine in your bladder, you might end up back in the bathroom sooner than you’d like.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-12.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you experience burning or stinging sensations when urinating, speak to your doctor; you may have a urinary tract infection.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Fatigue\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Fatigue\">Fatigue</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Take cat naps throughout the day. Sometimes the best way to deal with fatigue is to give into it. If you’re feeling really tired, take a short nap or rest your eyes for a while until you get your energy back.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-13.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Fatigue doesn’t usually last forever—by your second trimester, you’ll probably be feeling more like yourself again.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Get at least 8 hours of sleep every night. It’s super important to get a deep, restful sleep to avoid being tired throughout the day. Go to bed early and try to get 8 hours of sleep (or more) at night.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a1/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-14.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Getting enough sleep is beneficial to your overall health, too.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Do a relaxing activity before bed to wind down. If you have trouble falling asleep, try taking a bath, listening to soothing music, or reading a book. You can start your soothing activity about an hour before bed to wind down and relax.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-15.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also try drinking sleepy time tea to soothe your body from the inside out.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Try some stress-relieving activities to keep yourself calm. When your stress levels are high, it’s much harder to get a restful night’s sleep. Try yoga, mediation, or exercise to soothe your mind and lower your stress levels.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-16.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Lowering your stress levels can seem impossible, but it will be better for your overall health and the health of your baby.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Aches and Pains\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Aches-and-Pains\">Aches and Pains</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Try <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Yoga\" title=\"Do Yoga\">yoga</a> to stretch your lower back and pelvis. Lower back pain is very common during the later stages of pregnancy. Try doing yoga that focuses on your back to relieve some aches and pains in the area.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-17.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 17.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-17.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-17.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>As a bonus, yoga is also a calming and relaxing activity you can use to soothe your mood.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Put your feet up on a stool when you’re sitting to help with back pain. If you feel a twinge in your lower back when you sit down, prop your feet up on a stool or ottoman. This will help stretch out your spine and take some pressure off your lower back.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-18.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 18.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-18.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-18.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Always try to find the most comfortable position for your body before sitting down for a long time. If your spine is crunched or your posture is hunched, you could be in for a sore back later on.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Avoid standing or sitting in one position for too long. If you have to stand up for a while, keep a stool or a chair nearby to take a rest. If you sit for most of the day, try to get up and walk around for a few minutes. This will help stretch your muscles and relieve some pain.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-19.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 19.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-19.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-19.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Even walking for 30 minutes a day can give you some light exercise while helping with muscle pain.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Increase your calcium intake to avoid leg cramps. Dairy, kale, soy beans, and oatmeal all contain dairy that can help you alleviate cramps. Try to incorporate these foods into your diet to avoid an annoying charlie horse in your legs.<sup id=\"_ref-23\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-23\">[23]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-20.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 20.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-20.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-20.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When you’re stretching in bed, try to keep your feet flexed rather than pointing your toes. This can help avoid a cramp before it starts.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Treat headaches with a cold compress. Headaches and migraines are fairly common during pregnancy, but it doesn’t mean they’re enjoyable. If you have a headache, get an ice pack and press it against your neck or your scalp to help relieve some pain.<sup id=\"_ref-24\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 24\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-24\">[24]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-21.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 21.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-21.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-21.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Talk to your doctor before taking any pain relievers. Paracetamol may be an option, but you probably don’t want to take it for a long period of time.<sup id=\"_ref-25\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 25\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-25\">[25]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Elevate your hands and feet if they get swollen. Lie on a bed or on the floor, then put your legs up on the wall, keeping your knees bent. Lift your arms up and rest them on a wall or a chair to keep them above your heart.<sup id=\"_ref-26\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 26\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_note-26\">[26]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-22.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cope With Pregnancy Discomforts Step 22.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-22.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-22.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your hands and feet are constantly swollen, you might be dehydrated. Try drinking at least 8 glasses of water per day.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Add an extra pillow or two to your bed to aid sleeping.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you have been vomiting a lot, drink lots of water to rehydrate.</li> \n  <li>Any discomfort that seems abnormal, unbearable, odd or painful for extended periods of time is a signal to see your doctor or midwife quickly.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Avoid-Round-Ligament-Pain\" title=\"Avoid Round Ligament Pain\">Avoid Round Ligament Pain</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"9fa2f9a3957211e50618d44a5b47a001","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn24@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-00-41-223_325533fe54908936.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":47994,"destBytes":31278,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn24@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-00-41-223_325533fe54908936.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn92@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-07-017_1258d1d00bf44abb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn23@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-06-053_57098491fab8ce57.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn75@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-06-790_e44f05d8b7ea2808.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn87@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-04-605_9d4557b0478255f5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn. th-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn41@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-07-282_a4c5eac0e18fd348.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-15.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn81@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-01-09-743_16a2f3b01597350c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-16.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-16.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn5@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-00-56-544_b381d9be7a9de63d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-17.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-17.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn11@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-04-817_3bd2147279af73b1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-18.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-18.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn65@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-57-167_654c6acad82e0cb7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-19.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-19.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn80@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-07-759_109535ac49e2abad.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-20.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-20.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn46@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-54-549_dbeb260439a1ce91.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-21.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-21.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-22.jpg/aid1824715-v4-728px-Cope-With-Pregnancy-Discomforts-Step-22.jpg":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607673631425},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","title":"How to Edge a Lawn","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Edge-a-Lawn","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>You’ve mowed your lawn, raked the leaves, and watered the flowers—but your lawn still looks a little unkempt. It’s probably the little bits of grass around the edge of your lawn that your mower can’t reach, which can be taken care of with an edger. Edging your lawn isn’t hard, and you can do it with a gas, electric, or manual tool. All you need is a little practice, and your lawn can look like it was done by a professional! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Edge-a-Lawn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Edge-a-Lawn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Power Edger or Weed Wacker\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Power-Edger-or-Weed-Wacker\">Power Edger or Weed Wacker</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Put on long pants, eye goggles, and gloves. Power edgers and weed wackers have a tendency to throw dirt and debris around as they work. If there are any small rocks in your lawn, those could get tossed up as well, so make sure your eyes, skin, and hands are covered up before you start.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Edge-a-Lawn#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Edge-a-Lawn-Step-1-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Edge a Lawn Step 1 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Edge-a-Lawn-Step-1-Version-5.jpg/aid1332841-v4-728px-Edge-a-Lawn-Step-1-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your tool is super loud (some gas ones are) you can also put on some ear plugs to protect your ears.</li> \n    <li>You should also warn anyone around you that you’re about to use your edger so they can get out of the way.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use your power edger or weed wacker around sidewalks and footpaths. When you edge your lawn, you have two options for which tool to use: an electric or gas powered tool, or a manual edging tool. Because you don't have the space to dig out extra mulch or dirt around sidewalks and footpaths, it's best to use a power edger in these situations.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Edge-a-Lawn#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Edge-a-Lawn-Step-2-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Edge a Lawn Step 2 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Edge-a-Lawn-Step-2-Version-5.jpg/aid1332841-v4-728px-Edge-a-Lawn-Step-2-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re going to buy a power tool, try to find one that’s lightweight so you don’t strain your back or your arms.</li> \n    <li>Purchase a few replacement blades for your edger too, just in case.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Start at one end of the lawn. Turn your edging tool on (for gas powered there will be a string to pull; for electric, just press the “on” button) and move to one edge of your lawn. Moving from end to end will be much easier than starting in the middle, so it’s best to work from one side to the other.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Edge-a-Lawn#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Edge-a-Lawn-Step-3-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Edge a Lawn Step 3 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b2/Edge-a-Lawn-Step-3-Version-5.jpg/aid1332841-v4-728px-Edge-a-Lawn-Step-3-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re worried about messing up, start edging your backyard first before you move to the front. That way you can get some practice before trying it out on the part of your yard that everyone will see.</li> \n    <li>If you have sprinklers in your lawn, mark where those are and be sure to stay away from them so you don’t damage your tool.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Hold your edging tool with the blade level to the ground. As you set up to start using your tool, position the blade (or the strings) so they’re level with the grass you’d like to cut. For some edgers, this may mean turning your tool on its side so it lines up with the edge of your lawn. Others, you just hold them straight.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Edge-a-Lawn#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Edge-a-Lawn-Step-4-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Edge a Lawn Step 4 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Edge-a-Lawn-Step-4-Version-5.jpg/aid1332841-v4-728px-Edge-a-Lawn-Step-4-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can hold your tool with both hands by the handle. This will help keep it steady and in place as you go.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut about deep. Much further down than that, and you run into the risk of cutting pipes or wires. Keep your tool about below the grass line to get a smooth, clean edge.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Edge-a-Lawn#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Edge-a-Lawn-Step-5-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Edge a Lawn Step 5 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Edge-a-Lawn-Step-5-Version-5.jpg/aid1332841-v4-728px-Edge-a-Lawn-Step-5-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can try out this depth and change it up if you don’t like it. It’s your lawn!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Walk forward slowly and take your time. Keep holding your tool by the handles straight out in front of you, trying to keep it as steady as you can. Engage your core and keep your shoulders down as you walk forward slowly to cut your grass as evenly as possible.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Edge-a-Lawn#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Edge-a-Lawn-Step-6-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Edge a Lawn Step 6 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Edge-a-Lawn-Step-6-Version-5.jpg/aid1332841-v4-728px-Edge-a-Lawn-Step-6-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>As you learn how to edge your lawn, you’ll pick up speed. Start slow at first so you don’t accidentally wobble or wiggle.</li> \n    <li>If you can, walk on the sidewalk or the footpath as you edge. This will be a flatter surface so you don’t accidentally cut a curve in your grass.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a leaf blower to clean up dirt or grass. If you’re edging along a sidewalk or a footpath, you might blow dirt or grass onto the concrete. If you want your lawn to look spotless, use a leaf blower to blow the dirt and grass back onto your lawn. If you don’t mind it, you don’t have to worry about it.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Edge-a-Lawn#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Edge-a-Lawn-Step-7-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Edge a Lawn Step 7 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Edge-a-Lawn-Step-7-Version-5.jpg/aid1332841-v4-728px-Edge-a-Lawn-Step-7-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This will make your lawn look like it’s been done by a professional.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Edge-a-Lawn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Manual Tool\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Manual-Tool\">Manual Tool</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Edge around flower beds and planters with a manual edger. Flower beds and planters are perfect for using a manual edge because you can afford to take away a little soil or mulch when you edge them. You also won’t spray a ton of grass and dirt around like you would with a power edger or weed wacker.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Edge-a-Lawn#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Edge-a-Lawn-Step-8-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Edge a Lawn Step 8 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Edge-a-Lawn-Step-8-Version-5.jpg/aid1332841-v4-728px-Edge-a-Lawn-Step-8-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Manual edgers take more time, but you can be more precise with them. They’re a nice way to start out if you’re nervous about edging or you have a small lawn.</li> \n    <li>Most manual tools look like a half-moon with a long, shovel-like handle.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drive the edging tool into the ground until the lip hits the soil. Line up your tool with the spot you’d like to edge, then shove it into the ground with the handle sticking straight up. This will create your edge, so make sure it’s positioned exactly where you’d like your edge to be.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Edge-a-Lawn#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Edge-a-Lawn-Step-9-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Edge a Lawn Step 9 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Edge-a-Lawn-Step-9-Version-5.jpg/aid1332841-v4-728px-Edge-a-Lawn-Step-9-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re having trouble, use your foot to stomp on the tool and drive it deeper.</li> \n    <li>Watch out for pipes and sprinklers! You can do some serious damage to anything underground with this tool.</li> \n    <li>If you’re edging around trees or shrubs, make sure you won’t hit any roots before you start edging.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Rock the edge from side to side, then pull the handle back. This will loosen up the soil enough to create your indentation. As you pull the handle back, the soil and grass will lift up out of the ground.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Edge-a-Lawn#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Edge-a-Lawn-Step-10-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Edge a Lawn Step 10 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/50/Edge-a-Lawn-Step-10-Version-5.jpg/aid1332841-v4-728px-Edge-a-Lawn-Step-10-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It’s super important to keep the handle straight up, even as you’re rocking it from side to side. As soon as you pull back on the handle, you’ll lift up the dirt.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Shovel up the loose soil to remove it from your lawn. If the soil is hard to get at right away, rake it into a pile before you shovel it up. You can store your loose dirt in a wheelbarrow and transfer it to another part of your yard to keep the edge of your lawn looking sharp.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Edge-a-Lawn#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Edge-a-Lawn-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Edge a Lawn Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Edge-a-Lawn-Step-11.jpg/aid1332841-v4-728px-Edge-a-Lawn-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your edging tool seems dull, use a file to sharpen the edges so they slice into the dirt easily.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Edge-a-Lawn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>You won't need to edge every time you mow the lawn. Use your edger and trim a clean line as you see the borders growing out.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Edge-a-Lawn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Don't scrape the edger blade against concrete. You'll ruin the blade.</li> \n  <li>Make sure no one else is near when you are running the edger as it throws debris.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Edge-a-Lawn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Edge-a-Lawn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Power Edger or Weed Wacker\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Power-Edger-or-Weed-Wacker_2\">Power Edger or Weed Wacker</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Lawn edger</li> \n  <li>Eye goggles</li> \n  <li>Gloves</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Edge-a-Lawn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Manual Tool\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Manual-Tool_2\">Manual Tool</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Manual edger</li> \n  <li>Shovel</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Edge-a-Lawn&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit
