</li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 06 Dec 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-1-Version-6.jpg/aid169186-v4-728px-Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-1-Version-6.jpg","linkMd5":"dacea3884e3111e2e656d70a42fb083b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn95@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-31-736_c833bac8d0133d77.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":47898,"destBytes":28088,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-1-Version-6.jpg/aid169186-v4-728px-Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-1-Version-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn95@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-31-736_c833bac8d0133d77.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8f/Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-5-Version-6.jpg/aid169186-v4-728px-Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-5-Version-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn68@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-01-04-295_ca7958800a3e5ff3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-7-Version-5.jpg/aid169186-v4-728px-Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-7-Version-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn67@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-09-603_b3efe8ca899e1a1d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-11-Version-4.jpg/aid169186-v4-728px-Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-11-Version-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn45@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-01-06-596_1613c16a57d5ed6a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-13-Version-4.jpg/aid169186-v4-728px-Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-13-Version-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn50@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-03-978_7119007ec4327142.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-14-Version-4.jpg/aid169186-v4-728px-Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-14-Version-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn98@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-00-56-378_3ac669bf4c05d5d4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/48/Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-15-Version-4.jpg/aid169186-v4-728px-Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-15-Version-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn33@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-56-736_616e714a79277f02.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-16-Version-4.jpg/aid169186-v4-728px-Make-Gummy-Bears-Step-16-Version-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn34@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-02-583_bbdca659379ada52.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607673631425},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","title":"How to Fix a Rubbing Door","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>We know that it’s pretty frustrating when you can’t open a door smoothly because it gets stuck in the frame. Your door might rub against the frame if it’s sagging or when it’s just a little too large, but luckily there are some really easy repairs. Adjusting your hinges will solve most of your problems for any type of door, but you may need to trim it if those don’t work. We’ll walk you through some of the most common solutions so your door opens and closes smoothly! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Rubbing-Door&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Rubbing-Door&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Simple Hinge Fixes\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Simple-Hinge-Fixes\">Simple Hinge Fixes</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Tighten the screws in the hinges if they feel loose. Over time, the screws in your hinges might come loose and cause your door to sag.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> If the top corner on the latch side of the door scrapes against the frame, then tighten the top hinge. For a door that rubs against the bottom of the frame on the latch side, then screw in the bottom hinge more.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Rubbing Door Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure you use a screwdriver that properly fits into the screws. If you use one that’s too large, you could strip the screw and make it more difficult to use.</li> \n    <li>You can check for loose hinges and screws by opening the door halfway and pulling the handle straight up. That way, you can see which hinges move around.</li> \n    <li>If the screws don’t stay tightened because the holes are stripped, keep reading on for a simple fix.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Place a screw in the top hinge if the jamb bulges. Some builders use screws that are long, so it’s more likely for the jamb to come loose. A longer screw will pull the jamb in tighter so it’s not scraping the door. Open your door and place a shim that’s thick on the floor underneath it. Take out any one of the screws from the top hinge using a screwdriver. Fit a wood or deck screw into the hole and screw it in until it’s flush with the hinge.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Rubbing Door Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The longer screw will pull the door jamb back against the frame so your door doesn’t rub against it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Switch a bent top hinge with the straight bottom one if your door sags. Over time, a heavier door can slightly bend the top hinge and cause it to sag. If this happens, open your door and tap out the pins in the hinges with a hammer and screwdriver. Pull the door straight out of the frame so you can access the hinges. Unscrew the top and bottom hinges from both the door and the frame. Reattach the bottom hinge on top and use the slightly bent one on the bottom.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Rubbing Door Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The bottom hinge usually stays straighter since it’s not supporting the weight of the door as much.</li> \n    <li>If your hinge is extremely deformed or broken, then you’ll have to replace it entirely.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Fill in stripped holes with a golf tee and wood glue if the hinges still feel loose. Tap the hinge pins out from your door using a hammer and screwdriver. Pull your door straight out of the frame. Then, unscrew the hinges to take them off of the frame. Cover a wooden golf tee with wood glue and push it as far into the loose screw hole as you can. Score the tee with a utility knife and break it off so it’s flush with the frame. Once the glue dries, install the hinges and screw into the golf tee.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Rubbing Door Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’ve already tried tightening your hinges and they’re still loose, this fix will give the screws a firmer grip.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Put a shim under the hinges when a door hangs unevenly. Remove the hinge pins from the door and lift it out of the frame. Next, unscrew the hinges from the frame, but leave the ones attached to your door. Trace the shape of the door hinge on a piece of cardboard and cut it out with a utility knife. Put the cardboard shim in the frame’s mortise, which is the recessed area where you place the hinge. Set the hinge on top of the shim and screw it back in. Try reinstalling your door and checking if it opens and closes smoothly.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Rubbing Door Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When it scrapes the bottom corner on the latch side, then shim the top hinge.</li> \n    <li>If your door scrapes the top corner, add a shim behind the bottom hinge.</li> \n    <li>If your door still rubs, you can add another shim under the hinge, but don’t let the front of your hinge extend past the mortise. Otherwise, your door will get looser over time.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Rubbing-Door&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Wood Door Trimming\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Wood-Door-Trimming\">Wood Door Trimming</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Mark the area where the door rubs against the frame. If you’re sure your hinges and door are hanging straight but it’s still rubbing, then it’s time to trim it smaller. Open and close your door a few times so you can find out where it’s rubbing against the jamb. Draw a line on the side of the door where it’s scraping along the frame.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Rubbing Door Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Your door jamb should always have about of space on each side.</li> \n    <li>If you have trouble finding where the door rubs against the frame, take a piece of cardboard that’s about thick, and slide it in the crack between the door and the frame. Make your marks where the cardboard gets stuck.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove the hinge pins to take the door out. Close your door and stand on the side where the hinge pins stick out from the frame. Position a screwdriver on the bottom of the pin and lightly tap it with a hammer so it pops out. Pull the pin out from the top of the hinge. Then remove the pin from the other hinge so you can slide your door out from the frame.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Rubbing Door Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/97/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It doesn’t matter which hinge pin you remove first.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Take the hinges off of the door if you need to shorten the width. When your door is too wide for the frame, always trim from the side with the hinges since the latch mechanism can be hard to reinstall. Use a screwdriver to remove the hinges from the door and set them aside.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Rubbing Door Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your door rubs against the top or bottom, you don’t need to take out any of the hardware.</li> \n    <li>Store the hinges and screws in a cup or plastic bag so you don’t misplace any of the pieces.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Run a planer along the edges if you only need to remove . Hold the door steady between your legs or lay it across some sawhorses so it doesn’t shift around. Set your planer against the edge that you’re trimming and apply light pressure as you push it along the wood. If you’re planing the latch side, follow along with the wood grain. For the top or bottom edges, work from the edges toward the center. Only remove about of wood at a time so you don’t cut off too much.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Rubbing Door Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you apply a lot of pressure to the planer, you could gouge deeper into the wood and damage your door.</li> \n    <li>Hollow-core doors have about of solid wood at the top and bottom that you can trim.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Test the door to see if it swings freely. After you trim your door, reattach any hardware that you removed and position the door back in the frame. Push the pins back through the hinges on the door so it hangs freely. Try opening and closing the door to see if it moves easily. If it doesn’t rub the edge anymore, then you can move on.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Rubbing Door Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your door still rubs the frame, make note of where it still scrapes and take it down again. Use your planer to smooth out any edges that are still raised.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Paint or refinish the cut edge of the door. The cut edge of your door might stand out if the natural wood is a different color. Take the door back down by removing the hinge pins. Use the same paint or stain you used on the door so it blends in. Apply 1–2 coats and let it dry completely so your door looks uniform.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Rubbing Door Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-12.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you cut the top or bottom of the door, you should still refinish the edge even when you can’t see it. Otherwise, moisture could get into the door and cause it to swell again.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Rehang the door back in the frame. Hold the door back in the jamb so its hinges line up with the ones in the frame. Push the pins back through the slots in the hinge so your door stays secured in place. Your door should open and close smoothly when you’re finished!<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Rubbing Door Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-13.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Rubbing-Door&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Rubbing-Door&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Sometimes doors can swell when it’s humid out since they absorb moisture. Try running an air conditioner or dehumidifier to see if it helps your problem.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Rubbing-Door&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Always use caution when you work with power tools so you don’t get injured.</li> \n  <li>If your door still doesn’t work properly, your foundation may have settled and made your frame crooked. Call a professional foundation repair specialist to check the problem.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Rubbing-Door&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Rubbing-Door&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Simple Hinge Fixes\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Simple-Hinge-Fixes_2\">Simple Hinge Fixes</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Screwdriver</li> \n  <li>wood or deck screws</li> \n  <li>Golf tee</li> \n  <li>Wood glue</li> \n  <li>Utility knife</li> \n  <li>Cardboard</li> \n  <li>Pencil</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Rubbing-Door&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Door Trimming\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Door-Trimming\">Door Trimming</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Pencil</li> \n  <li>Hammer</li> \n  <li>Screwdriver</li> \n  <li>Planer</li> \n  <li>Circular saw</li> \n  <li>Utility knife</li> \n  <li>Paint or stain</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Rubbing-Door&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Hang-a-Prehung-Door\" title=\"Hang a Prehung Door\">Hang a Prehung Door</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"e821d321ab96f986f499288861151be0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn28@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-00-31-845_1737b1fe30b1ee0e.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":42690,"destBytes":21474,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn28@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-00-31-845_1737b1fe30b1ee0e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn85@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-01-07-863_8adc36705cf1ccd5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn99@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-01-09-198_36d883c8d9f1695b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn18@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-59-416_1e4979630840f3a5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn55@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-00-58-355_6f169b3b5242caef.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn90@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-01-10-284_091daec4440c0efd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/97/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn96@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-02-086_75513e7aa54fa7e9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn44@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-01-03-827_a76bb622e7d7f764.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn53@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-08-732_77e2885958704d0e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-12.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn8@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-07-267_deed1f5318b4ca47.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-13.jpg/aid1354687-v4-728px-Fix-a-Rubbing-Door-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn45@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-00-56-951_af211eece3f10a96.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607673631433},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","title":"How to Remove Ice from a Car","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>We’ve all been there: it’s freezing cold and you’ve got to get to work soon. You walk outside to find your car covered in ice. Great, now what? Have no fear! You can get that ice off quickly and easily so you can get out on the road soon. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Ice-from-a-Car&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Ice-from-a-Car&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Defrosting and Scraping\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Defrosting-and-Scraping\">Defrosting and Scraping</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Start your car and turn on your defrost setting. Fire up your car’s engine so it can start heating up. Turn on the heater and set it to the defrost setting so the warm air flows over your windshield to start warming it up and melting the ice.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Ice from a Car Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2e/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It may take a few minutes for the air coming out to warm up.</li> \n    <li>If your car has defrost vents on your side windows and side mirrors, turn them on as well.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Set the temperature to full heat and the air to recirculate. Find your temperature button or slide and set it to the highest heat setting possible. Look for an airflow setting on your A/C panel and adjust it so the air inside the car is being recirculated.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Ice from a Car Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Recirculating the air can help it heat up faster and warms up the air inside the car which can help defrost any other windows with ice on them.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Turn on your headlights to melt any ice on them. Flick on your car’s headlights and taillights so the bulbs can start warming up, which will melt the ice and make it easier to remove. Leave the lights on while you remove the ice from your windows to give it some time to heat up.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Ice from a Car Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Use a plastic scraper to scrape off the ice from your windows. Take a plastic glass scraper and wedge it beneath the layer of ice on the outside of the glass. Drag the scraper over the surface of the glass to scrape off the ice. Work your way around your car and remove the ice from all of your windows so you’re able to see in every direction when you drive.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Ice from a Car Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Avoid using anything but a scraper designed to remove ice from cars so you don’t scratch the glass.</li> \n    <li>If there’s ice covering your headlights, scrape it off as well.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Spray a rubbing alcohol and water mixture on stubborn ice. If the ice is too thick or difficult to scrape off with just your scraper, take a clean spray bottle and add 1 part rubbing alcohol and 2 parts water. Shake it up well to fully combine the mixture. Apply the solution liberally over your windshield and windows to start melting the ice and make it easier to scrape off.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Ice from a Car Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you plan to keep a spray bottle full of the mixture, keep it stored in your home so it stays at room temperature. If you store it in your car it could freeze.</li> \n    <li>You can also add a few drops of dish soap to the mixture to act as a surfactant, which can help the solution coat the ice more evenly.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Ice-from-a-Car&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Getting Rid of Ice and Snow\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Getting-Rid-of-Ice-and-Snow\">Getting Rid of Ice and Snow</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Brush off any snow on your car with a broom or show brush. Snow likes to settle on the roof, hood, and trunk of your car and could become a hazard out on the road, so take a sturdy show brush or a broom and give your car a good sweeping. Knock off snow you find stuck on top of any ice on your car as well to make the ice easier to scrape off.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Ice from a Car Step 6 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Whatever you do, don’t use a snow shovel to brush the snow off of your car. It’s way too easy to scratch up your paint job or crack a window.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Smack your hood and trunk with a flattened hand. Break up any thin layers of ice that may have formed over the surface of your car so they’re easier to brush off. A good, open-handed smack on the hood as well as your trunk should do the trick.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Ice from a Car Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Use lock de-icer if your car’s locks are frozen. If you can’t unlock your car because a layer of ice has them frozen, apply a commercial lock de-icer to get them working again. Spray the liquid into the keyhole and wait for it to melt the ice. Then, unlock your car door.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Ice from a Car Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Lock for lock de-icer at your local auto supply store or department store. You can also order it online.</li> \n    <li>You can also make your own de-icer by mixing together of rubbing alcohol and of water in a spray bottle. Spray the mixture onto your keyholes to melt the ice.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make sure all of the ice and snow is removed before you drive. Walk around your car and inspect it for any ice or snow that may still be on it. If you find any, scrape or brush it off. Any ice or snow that you leave on could come loose and fly off while you’re driving, which could potentially cause an accident.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Ice from a Car Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It can be tempting to try to get just enough ice off so you can see, especially if you’re late or in a hurry. But it could be really dangerous. Take an extra moment to remove all of the ice before you drive.</li> \n    <li>In many places driving with snow and ice still on your car is also illegal and you could be faced with a hefty fine.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Ice-from-a-Car&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Ice Prevention\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ice-Prevention\">Ice Prevention</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Park your car in a garage if you can. If you have a covered garage, use it! Park your car there so it isn’t exposed to the elements and forms ice on the windshield and windows overnight.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Ice from a Car Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Parking under a covered carport can also help prevent snow and ice from building up on your car.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Spray a mixture of vinegar and water on your windshield at night. Combine 3 parts white vinegar with 1 part water in a spray bottle and shake it up to mix it well. Pretreat your windshield with the solution and then wipe up the excess to leave a thin layer on the glass that will help keep ice from forming overnight.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Ice from a Car Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don’t leave too much liquid on the glass or it could potentially freeze if it gets cold enough.</li> \n    <li>FYI: according to AAA, some glass professionals believe that exposing your windshield to liquid vinegar too often could damage the glass.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cover your windshield at night as an alternative. Another option you can use if you want to keep ice from forming on your windshield overnight is to cover it with a windshield cover, tarp, towel, a folded sheet, or even bath mats. Cover the glass so none of it is exposed to prevent ice from being able to form on it.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Ice from a Car Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-12.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can find windshield covers that use magnets to stay attached to your windshield at your local auto supply shop. You can also order them online.</li> \n    <li>You may have heard that soaking windshield covers in salt water can help prevent ice. While they can stop ice from forming, they can also damage your car’s wax and finish. You may just want to use a dry cover.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <p><br /> </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Ice-from-a-Car&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you have any problems or your car breaks down, call a roadside assistance company like AAA to help you out.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Ice-from-a-Car&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Never get on the road with ice or snow still on your car. It could cause an accident and is illegal in many places.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Ice-from-a-Car&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Ice-from-a-Car&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap   <li id=\"_note-13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car#_ref-13\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 07 Dec 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2e/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"46c873cdf9e481dbab867fb28097648e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn55@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-52-330_d8a3cd33104dac41.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":78984,"destBytes":44792,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2e/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn55@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-52-330_d8a3cd33104dac41.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn30@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-00-59-688_bfa9b9f93e180034.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn20@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-03-733_953bcbd75fb82af5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn15@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-06-015_0dcc5d8264368850.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn78@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-00-56-005_6e7e524bef859f3c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn58@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-02-871_1e0f37b453e48563.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn93@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-59-182_21ec0886bb622425.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn88@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-00-502_87a6fc2746b0558e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn14@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-00-56-661_d5bf089072029a8b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn23@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-09-170_3d21a3127e767327.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn2@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-00-56-429_f17fd8a0c18f1981.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-12.jpg/aid1297914-v4-728px-Remove-Ice-from-a-Car-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn38@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-03-078_1b1e4f5358f2eeb5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607673631383},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","title":"How to Comment As a Page on Facebook","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>This wikiHow teaches you how to leave a comment on a Facebook Page (for a brand, service, organization, or public figure) as a Page you manage. Commenting on other Pages with your own organization or brand name is a great way to build community and increase your Page's reach. You must be a Page admin, editor, or moderator to comment on as a Page. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Using a Phone or Tablet\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-a-Phone-or-Tablet\">Using a Phone or Tablet</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Open Facebook on your Android, iPhone, or iPad. If you're already signed in, you will see your personal news feed.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Go to the Page on which you want to comment. To search for a Page by name, tap the magnifying glass icon at the top of Facebook, type the name, and then tap it in the search results.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Scroll to the post you want to comment on. You'll see your own personal profile photo at the bottom-right corner.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6a/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Tap your profile photo. This displays a list of all other Pages you can comment as.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a6/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Select the Page you want to comment as. This changes your profile icon below the post to the one connected to your Page.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Tap below the post. This opens the typing area.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Type your comment and tap the Send icon. The Send icon is the blue paper airplane on the right side of the typing area. This shares your comment on the post and makes it appear as though it comes from your Page.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ad/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-7.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Using a Computer\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-a-Computer\">Using a Computer</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Go to <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com\">https://www.facebook.com</a> in a web browser. If you're already signed in, you'll see your personal news feed. If you're not signed in yet, go ahead and do that now.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-8.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Navigate to the Page on which you want to comment. To search for a Page, click the <b>Search</b> bar at the top-left corner, type the Page name, and then click it in the search results.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-9.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Scroll to the post on which you want to comment. You'll want to make sure you can see the \"Write a comment\" field beneath the post.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-10.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Click your profile image below the post. It's in a tiny circle at the bottom-right corner of the post. A list of all Pages you administer, edit, or moderate will appear.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-11.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Click the Page you want to comment as. This switches the previous profile image that appeared below the post to that of your Page.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-12.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Type your comment and press or . When your comment is published, it will appear as though it was posted by your Page and not your personal account.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Comment As a Page on Facebook Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7b/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-13.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>It's not possible to comment as your Page on a personal Facebook user's post—only on posts from other Pages.</li> \n  <li>Another thing you can do with your Page to expand your reach is to join Facebook Groups as your Page. To do this, select <b>+ Join Group</b> on the group's main page, select the option to join as your Page, and then tap <b>Join Group</b>.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap\">\n  <ol
