</ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 08 Dec 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"8bd4652464f109c8eb119834f65ae0f2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn92@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-00-43-800_c6275d45592dd0c4.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":54160,"destBytes":31130,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn92@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-00-43-800_c6275d45592dd0c4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn46@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-00-55-747_6479d4bffbbb6583.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6a/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn25@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-07-117_ebd22c44c763328c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a6/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn84@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-01-05-653_63180f365ca751d4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn18@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-01-002_b70d6ddd269235dc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn86@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-08-715_960d93b0c5beca59.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ad/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-7.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn58@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-04-041_6f074844c0e4df19.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-8.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn22@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-08-094_d0150bd8c356879c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-9.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn8@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-08-918_cc18cd2321328956.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-10.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn73@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-01-732_3b5713e8754d797a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-11.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn61@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-07-674_b0178dcbb12a8584.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-12.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn24@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-54-383_f0d0f91cae1713c3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7b/Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-13.jpg/aid8827447-v4-728px-Comment-As-a-Page-on-Facebook-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn74@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-08-611_189ad8bc4d8a1624.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607673631405},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","title":"How to Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>The joy of decorating for the holidays can be dampened a little by a pesky half string of lights that refuses to glow. While your instinct may be to just toss the whole string and buy a replacement, there are some simple measures you can take to possibly repair the string. After identifying the problem, you can try replacing any bad bulbs or fuses, or repairing a bad shunt (in incandescent bulbs only). With luck, your holiday decorating will brighten back up! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Troubleshooting the Problem\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Troubleshooting-the-Problem\">Troubleshooting the Problem</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Remove corrosion from the plug prongs and plug the string in again. If the plug prongs on your string of lights look dark or corroded, bring back their brass shine by rubbing them with a sheet of medium or fine grit sandpaper. Use a clean cloth or tack cloth to wipe away any sanding dust, then try plugging in the lights again.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-01.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 01.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-01.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-01.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Corrosion on the plug prongs adds resistance that may prevent the necessary voltage from flowing through the light string. Once you clear the corrosion away, your lights may work again!</li> \n    <li>If this doesn’t work, move on to other troubleshooting measures.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Plug a light string that works into the half-out string. In other words, plug one end of your half-working string into an outlet, then connect a fully-functioning string to its other end. Before doing this, confirm that the second string is fully functional by plugging it into the outlet on its own.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-02-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 02 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-02-Version-2.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-02-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If the second string still works, then you likely have a problem with a bad bulb or fuse in the first string.</li> \n    <li>If the functioning string doesn’t work when plugged into the half-working string, there’s likely a problem with the wiring or, if you have incandescent bulbs, one or more shunts within the bulbs.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Run a bulb tester over the string to find any bad bulbs. If you’ve narrowed down your likely problem to bad bulbs or bad fuses, use a bulb tester if you have one. Plug in the string of lights, then test each dark bulb by either touching it with or inserting it into the tester, depending on your model.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-03.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 03.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d1/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-03.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-03.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Depending on your tester model, it may beep or light up when you find a bad bulb.</li> \n    <li>If you find one bad bulb, keep checking for more. Mark each one with masking tape so you know which ones to replace.</li> \n    <li>Move on to replacing any bad bulbs that you find. If you don’t find any bad bulbs, move on to checking and replacing the fuses.</li> \n    <li>You can get a bulb tester anywhere holiday lights are sold. Consider buying a combination model that includes a tester and repair tool.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Changing a Bad Bulb\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Changing-a-Bad-Bulb\">Changing a Bad Bulb</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Pull up from the plastic seat of the bulb, not the bulb itself. If you tug on the bulb itself, you’ll probably just pull it and its 2 lead wires out of the plastic seat that fits into the socket. Instead, work your thumbnail into the small gap between the bulb seat and the socket exterior, then lift the seat and bulb together out of the socket.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-04.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 04.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/14/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-04.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-04.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For your safety, always unplug the string of lights before replacing a bulb.</li> \n    <li>Some bulb seats have plastic latches that snap onto the socket exterior. Simply lift up any latches before pulling out the bulb and seat.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a replacement bulb that’s an exact match. Holiday lights tend to look very similar, but they’re not universal. Different manufacturers may use slightly different bulbs, seats, sockets, and/or lead wires, any of which may prevent a non-matching replacement bulb from working properly. If you have the replacement bulbs that came with the string, use them first.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-05.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 05.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/90/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-05.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-05.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When buying strings of lights, consider buying an extra string for every 3 or so that you buy—that is, buy 8 strings if you need 6. Use the extra string(s) simply for backup bulbs. Pull the bulbs from the extra string(s), put them in a labeled bag, and store the bulb-free string(s) for use if the wiring on one of your other strings goes bad.</li> \n    <li>If you don't have an exact match, don't try to force a bulb that doesn't completely fit into place. Non-matching bulbs are far more likely to fail and, in very rare cases, may present a fire hazard if they short. It's safer to just buy replacement light strings.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Press the new bulb securely in place, then test it. Check to make sure that the 2 small lead wires are snug along opposite sides of the bulb seat. Then, press the bulb straight down into the socket until the seat is snugly in place. Plug the string of lights back in—if the whole string lights up, you’re all set!<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-06.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 06.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-06.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-06.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If all the lights don’t come on, run the tester over your replacement bulb to make sure it is seated properly. If it isn’t, try removing and re-setting it again. If it is, move on to checking for other problems with the string of lights.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Replacing the Fuse\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Replacing-the-Fuse\">Replacing the Fuse</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Slide open the fuse compartment with a small screwdriver. On the male-side end of the string of lights (the side with the plug prongs), look for a small compartment cover. Slide this cover out toward the plug prongs to expose the fuse compartment.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-07.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 07.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/17/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-07.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-07.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>A small screwdriver comes in handy here, although you may be able to slide open the compartment with an opened paperclip or your fingernail.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use an opened paperclip or other small tool to remove the fuses. In nearly all cases you’ll find 2 small fuses inside the compartment—they look like tiny glass capsules with metallic tips. Use the end of an opened paperclip as a lever to get underneath and lift up each fuse.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-08.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 08.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-08.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-08.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Check for signs that one or both fuses have blown. If the glass section of the fuse is dark or looks burned on the inside, the fuse has blown. If you can’t tell for sure, it’s best to assume the fuse has blown and replace it.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-09.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 09.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-09.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-09.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>A blown fuse occurs when the small sacrificial wire within the fuse melts. It’s meant to do so as a protective measure if an excessive current passes through the line, although fuses can fail for other reasons as well.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Install replacement fuses that are the same size and amperage. Unlike bulbs, holiday light fuses usually are identical across brands. They’re nearly always the same size and rated for 3 amps, as indicated by a “3A” notation on the fuse. For the easiest replacement option, use the extra fuses that came with the string of lights.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-10.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Push your replacement fuses down into the compartment until they are fully seated. The tip of a pen may come in handy to help push the fuse in place. Slide the cover back over the compartment, then plug in the string and see if all the lights work.</li> \n    <li>If replacing any bad bulbs and fuses hasn’t solved your problem, you likely have an issue with a bad shunt (in incandescent lights) or bad wiring.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Fixing a Damaged Shunt\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Fixing-a-Damaged-Shunt\">Fixing a Damaged Shunt</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Purchase a holiday light repair tool. If you use a lot of light strings in your holiday decorations, a light repair tool can be a wise investment. Look for them wherever holiday lights are sold, and expect to pay around $25-$30 USD.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-11.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>A good light repair tool is multi-functional. It should act as a voltage detector, bulb tester, bulb remover, and shunt repairer.</li> \n    <li>The best-known option is likely the LightKeeper Pro, which looks like a small plastic pistol.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove a bulb in or close to the section that won’t light. If your light repair tool has a bulb remover, use it according to the product instructions. Otherwise, use your thumbnail to pry the plastic seat of the bulb from the socket.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-12.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can remove any bulb in the darkened section, or even a lit bulb that’s near the darkened section. Unplug the light string before removing a bulb, though.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Insert the tool in the socket and send one or more pulses as instructed. The LightKeeper Pro, for instance, has a prong that fits into the light socket. Once it’s in place, pull the trigger on the device to send a pulse of energy through the string of lights.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-13.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Follow the specific instructions for your light repair tool. You may be instructed to trigger several pulses through the light string.</li> \n    <li>Shunts are small backup wires inside each incandescent bulb that are meant to take over if the filament in the bulb fails, thereby maintaining a completed circuit. The pulses from the light repair tool should be enough to melt the insulated coating and activate any shunts that aren’t working.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Replace the bulb and test the light string again. Remove your light repair tool and press the bulb back into the socket firmly. With any luck, the entire string will light up when you plug in the lights!<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix Christmas Lights That Are Half Out Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-14.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If the string still won’t light fully, it’s probably time to just replace the whole thing.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Most light strings are actually 2 separate strings that are wired together in the middle. This is the case if your lights have a section near the middle with only 2 coiled wires, instead of the 3 you’ll find elsewhere. In theory, this means you can cut off the non-functioning half of the light string and splice in a new end plug or half string of lights. However, consider this only if you have moderate or higher electrical skills.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Do not attempt to replace bulbs or fuses when a light string is plugged in. The risk of electric shock is real and should not be taken lightly.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-01.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-01.jpg","linkMd5":"8e43a239627e8b35ed988cf6c24553a2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn100@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-00-31-887_fa92aa98b2fad6b0.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":37030,"destBytes":40194,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-01.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-01.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn100@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-00-31-887_fa92aa98b2fad6b0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-02-Version-2.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-02-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn36@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-01-02-749_8ff7c325a96d275b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d1/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-03.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-03.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn1@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-09-872_0a876dafdd35b116.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/14/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-04.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-04.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn88@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-01-05-770_39aef2a7058d8e2d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/90/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-05.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-05.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn77@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-09-643_def76dfb7d5f83fe.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-06.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-06.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn15@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-01-07-056_2d6a83122919bd11.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/17/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-07.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-07.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn78@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-00-58-844_10691cd0a88e30b7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-08.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-08.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn93@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-01-09-708_eb13009e463ef4dc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-09.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-09.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn50@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-00-55-786_93bf714c34e4f452.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-10.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn70@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-00-54-875_cc02d46a35e64d70.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-11.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn76@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-04-563_8b1f0320563e71ba.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-12.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn73@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-00-57-147_efc195179d8d2f96.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-13.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn45@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-01-07-462_a99e8ee50e47503f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-14.jpg/aid11407630-v4-728px-Fix-Christmas-Lights-That-Are-Half-Out-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn2@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-00-59-127_8f81e803e0adfc05.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607673631412},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","title":"How to Use an Oatmeal Bath","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Oatmeal baths are a tried and true way to soothe away your itchy, irritated skin. Believe it or not, these baths can help with a variety of issues. If you have a lot of colloidal oatmeal (a medicinal type of oatmeal) lying around, take a peek at this list to see how oatmeal baths can possibly help you in the future.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> If you just have regular oats, grind them to a fine powder with a food processor so they’ll be ready to mix with your bath water!<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup> </p>\n <p><br /> </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Soothe itchy skin.[3]\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Soothe-itchy-skin.[3]\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Soothe-itchy-skin..5B3.5D\">Soothe itchy skin.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-an-Oatmeal-Bath\" title=\"Make an Oatmeal Bath\">Whip up a simple bath</a> with 1 cup (129 g) of colloidal oatmeal. Fill your tub with lukewarm water, then sprinkle in the colloidal oatmeal. Relax and unwind for about 15 minutes, which can help relieve your itchy skin. When soaked in water, oatmeal does a great job of sticking to your skin, which helps protect and soothe your skin.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use an Oatmeal Bath Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1609397-v4-728px-Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Scientific evidence also shows that oatmeal has some antioxidant and anti-inflammatory qualities, which are great for your skin.</li> \n    <li>Don’t use hot water in your oatmeal baths—this can actually irritate your skin.</li> \n    <li>If you don’t have any colloidal oatmeal on hand, blend 1 cup (129 g) of oatmeal in a food processor first until it turns into a powder.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Give your itchy dog some relief.[4]\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Give-your-itchy-dog-some-relief.[4]\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Give-your-itchy-dog-some-relief..5B4.5D\">Give your itchy dog some relief.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Fill your tub with lukewarm water and mix in ⅓ to 1 cup (43-129 g) of ground oatmeal. Stir the powdered oatmeal into the bath water until it looks milky, and coax your furry friend into the tub. Gently ladle the bath water over your dog’s fur and skin, waiting 10 minutes for the oatmeal to really soak in. Rinse off the leftover oatmeal with warm water until your pet’s fur and skin is completely clean. Then, guide your pooch out of the tub and towel-dry them off.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use an Oatmeal Bath Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid1609397-v4-728px-Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Small dogs only need about ⅓ cup (43 g) of colloidal oatmeal in the bath, while bigger dogs might need ½ to 1 cup (65-129 g).</li> \n    <li>If your dog still seems itchy after the bath, call your vet for advice.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Treat eczema and psoriasis.[5]\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Treat-eczema-and-psoriasis.[5]\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Treat-eczema-and-psoriasis..5B5.5D\">Treat eczema and psoriasis.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Fill up your tub with lukewarm water and mix in the colloidal oatmeal. Stir the powder into the bath water and soak for about 10-15 minutes. Towel-dry yourself off as you step out of the bath, so your skin is damp but not dripping wet. Then, rub your moisturizer of choice into your skin right after.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use an Oatmeal Bath Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1609397-v4-728px-Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>A nice soak in an oatmeal bath can help loosen some of the psoriasis “scales” on your skin.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Soothe a yeast infection.[7]\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Soothe-a-yeast-infection.[7]\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Soothe-a-yeast-infection..5B7.5D\">Soothe a yeast infection.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup></span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Give yourself temporary relief by soaking in a lukewarm bath. Yeast infections can leave you with an overwhelming itch and burning feeling that just won’t go away. While it’s best to <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Get-Rid-of-a-Yeast-Infection-at-Home\">tackle yeast infections at the source</a>, an oatmeal bath can give you some relief from the more obvious symptoms.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use an Oatmeal Bath Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1609397-v4-728px-Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Cope with itchy chicken pox.[8]\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Cope-with-itchy-chicken-pox.[8]\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cope-with-itchy-chicken-pox..5B8.5D\">Cope with itchy chicken pox.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup></span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Enjoy a 20-30 minute oatmeal when you have chicken pox. Cool or lukewarm water can help soothe away the itch—it’s really up to your personal preference. Since chicken pox tends to flare up all over, give yourself 20-30 minutes to soak instead of the usual 15-minute bath.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use an Oatmeal Bath Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1609397-v4-728px-Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you plan on washing up during your oatmeal bath, choose a mild soap that won’t irritate your skin even more.</li> \n    <li>Pat your skin dry after the bath instead of rubbing it.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Treat poison ivy rashes.[9]\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Treat-poison-ivy-rashes.[9]\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Treat-poison-ivy-rashes..5B9.5D\">Treat poison ivy rashes.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Take quick oatmeal baths to cope with the itchiness. Poison ivy, sumac, or oak rashes are no fun, especially if they’re all over your skin. Soak in the tub for a few minutes and see if the oatmeal helps relieve any of the itchiness.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use an Oatmeal Bath Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid1609397-v4-728px-Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When you’re not soaking in an oatmeal bath, treat the rash with calamine lotion, hydrocortisone cream, or a cool compress.</li> \n    <li>Antihistamine pills might also help make the itching go away.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Soothe away hives.[10]\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Soothe-away-hives.[10]\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Soothe-away-hives..5B10.5D\">Soothe away hives.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Draw a cool oatmeal bath for yourself if you develop hives. Hives are typically the result of an allergic reaction, and are very unpredictable. Fill your tub with cool water, then sprinkle in some colloidal oatmeal. Soak in the tub for a few minutes and see if your hives go away.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use an Oatmeal Bath Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-7.jpg/aid1609397-v4-728px-Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Take a bath if your skin is irritated from cancer treatment.[11]\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Take-a-bath-if-your-skin-is-irritated-from-cancer-treatment.[11]\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Take-a-bath-if-your-skin-is-irritated-from-cancer-treatment..5B11.5D\">Take a bath if your skin is irritated from cancer treatment.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Cancer treatments can really ravage your skin with unpleasant side effects. You may notice unexplained rashes, or feel like your skin is sunburned. Add some colloidal oatmeal to your bath to help ease away these unpleasant symptoms. Lukewarm or cool water is best for these kinds of baths.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use an Oatmeal Bath Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a6/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-8.jpg/aid1609397-v4-728px-Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Always talk to a doctor if you’re dealing with any unexplainable side effects from your treatment.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>There are a lot of skincare products out there with oatmeal included, like cleansers, emollient creams, and lotions.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Aveeno is a really popular brand of colloidal, bath-ready oatmeal.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Oatmeal baths can also help with pesky bug bites.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Oatmeal baths are a great home remedy for itchy and uncomfortable skin, but they’re not a permanent solution. Talk to your doctor for more specific suggestions for your condition or ailment.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" -an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-8.jpg/aid1609397-v4-728px-Use-an-Oatmeal-Bath-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn29@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-01-01-306_0801f45a37d2a747.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607673631423},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:00:31","title":"How to Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Having white teeth can be a major confidence boost. Fortunately, you may not need to spend lots of money on whitening kits or professional treatments. Brushing or rinsing with baking soda could help whiten your teeth, but be aware you should use it carefully. To prevent dental erosion, brush with baking soda in moderation and avoid using too much force. Bear in mind discoloration may point to dental issues, so try to see a dentist if you haven't had a checkup in a while. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Brushing with a Baking Soda Paste\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Brushing-with-a-Baking-Soda-Paste\">Brushing with a Baking Soda Paste</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Mix together baking soda and water. In a small cup, mix ¼ to ½ teaspoon (1½ to 3g) of baking soda with enough water to form a paste. A paste of about 2 parts of baking soda mixed with 1 part of water is easier to apply and more effective than baking soda alone.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-1-Version-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 1 Version 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-1-Version-11.jpg/aid1763-v4-728px-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-1-Version-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Avoid making a paste with baking soda and lemon, strawberry, or any other fruit juice. Fruit juices are acidic and could erode your teeth's enamel, especially when combined with baking soda or other abrasive products.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Brush-Your-Teeth\" title=\"Brush Your Teeth\">Brush</a> your teeth with the baking soda paste for 1 to 2 minutes. Dip a soft-bristled brush into the paste, and gently scrub your teeth using circular motions. Brush all around instead of scrubbing 1 spot for the entire 2 minutes. Be sure not to brush hard or you might hurt your teeth.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-2-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 2 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-2-Version-7.jpg/aid1763-v4-728px-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-2-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Alternatively, use your fingertips to gently rub your teeth with the paste. Rub in soft circles, and don’t use too much force.</li> \n    <li>If you have receding gums, avoid brushing the base of your teeth and around your gum line with baking soda. The substance that covers your teeth below the gums is softer than enamel and prone to damage.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Rinse out your mouth when you’re finished brushing. After brushing for 2 minutes, spit out the baking soda and rinse your mouth with water or mouthwash. Give your toothbrush a thorough rinse as well.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-3-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 3 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a5/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-3-Version-7.jpg/aid1763-v4-728px-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-3-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Note that you shouldn’t rinse after brushing with a fluoride toothpaste, as rinsing reduces fluoride’s beneficial effects. For this reason, don’t brush or rinse with baking soda right after brushing with regular toothpaste. If you really need to rinse away visible residue after using regular toothpaste, use as little water as possible.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Repeat every other day for up to 2 weeks. At most, brush your teeth with baking soda paste every other day for 1 to 2 weeks. Then cut back to doing it just once or twice a week. Since it’s abrasive, using baking soda more frequently may damage your teeth.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-4-Version-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 4 Version 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-4-Version-8.jpg/aid1763-v4-728px-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-4-Version-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep in mind that brushing your teeth with baking soda should not replace brushing your teeth with regular toothpaste. Brushing twice a day with a fluoride toothpaste, flossing daily, and regular dental checkups are the best ways to keep your teeth healthy.</li> \n    <li>Before brushing with baking soda, check with your dentist to see if your teeth are healthy enough for this method. Your teeth may be sensitive to abrasion, and baking soda may cause irreversible dental erosion.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Trying Alternative Methods\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Trying-Alternative-Methods\">Trying Alternative Methods</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Mix 2 parts of baking soda with 1 part of 1% to 3% hydrogen peroxide. <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Hydrogen-Peroxide\" title=\"Whiten Teeth With Hydrogen Peroxide\">Hydrogen peroxide</a> may whiten teeth, but you need to use it with caution. To try this method, mix 2 parts of baking soda with 1 part of 1% to 3% hydrogen peroxide to form a paste. Brush your teeth with the mixture for 1 to 2 minutes, then rinse with water.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-5-Version-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 5 Version 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-5-Version-10.jpg/aid1763-v4-728px-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-5-Version-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure you use hydrogen peroxide with a concentration of 3% or less. Brush with hydrogen peroxide and baking soda once a week at most.</li> \n    <li>Stop brushing and rinse your mouth with cool water if you feel a burning sensation. Don’t use this method if you have receding or sensitive gums, as hydrogen peroxide can cause irritation and damage exposed roots.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Brush your teeth with a mix of baking soda and fluoride toothpaste. Squeeze your regular toothpaste onto your toothbrush, then sprinkle a pinch of baking soda on top. Brush your teeth as you normally would for 2 minutes with soft, circular motions. Then spit and, if you need to rinse away white residue, swish your mouth with a little water.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-6-Version-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 6 Version 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-6-Version-8.jpg/aid1763-v4-728px-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-6-Version-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>As with a baking soda and water paste, brush with baking soda and toothpaste in moderation. Try it every other day for 1 to 2 weeks at first, then brush with baking soda once or twice a week at most.</li> \n    <li>You can also purchase a toothpaste that already contains baking soda. In the United States, look for a product that carries the ADA (American Dental Association) Seal of Acceptance, and use it as directed.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>If you have sensitive teeth or dental erosion, avoid using toothpastes that contain baking soda or are branded as whitening products.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Gargle with a baking soda and water rinse. Combine 1 teaspoon (6 g) of baking soda and of water in a glass, then stir the mixture until the baking soda is evenly distributed. Take a sip, gargle for about 30 seconds, then spit out the mixture. Repeat the steps until you’ve finished the entire glass.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-7-Version-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 7 Version 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-7-Version-9.jpg/aid1763-v4-728px-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-7-Version-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The baking soda rinse won't erode your teeth, so it's safe to gargle with it daily.</li> \n    <li>Gargling with a baking soda rinse whitens your teeth indirectly. Baking soda neutralizes acids, so it helps fight dental erosion caused by acidic foods and beverages. It can also help fight bacteria that cause decay and promote good bacteria that create a protective layer on your teeth.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Don't brush a single area of your mouth for too long. Divide 1 to 1 ½ minutes evenly among your top teeth, then brush your bottom teeth for a total of 1 to 1 ½ minutes.</li> \n  <li>Remember not to brush with a mix of baking soda and lemon juice or other acidic substances.</li> \n  <li>Avoid brushing your gums with baking soda or hydrogen peroxide.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>See a dentist if you’re concerned about whitening your teeth. Stains or discoloration may be signs of problems that require professional dental care.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Don’t brush your teeth with baking soda or abrasive toothpastes if you have sensitive teeth, which may indicate dental erosion. Brushing with abrasive products will just make matters worse.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Avoid brushing with baking soda or hydrogen peroxide if you have braces or a permanent retainer.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>To prevent uneven coloration or damage to your dental work, don’t use hydrogen peroxide or at-home bleaching kits if you have crowns, caps, or veneers.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" Teeth</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Get-Your-Children-to-Brush-Their-Teeth\" title=\"Get Your Children to Brush Their Teeth\">Get Your Children to Brush Their Teeth</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Care-for-Your-Teeth\" title=\"Care for Your Teeth\">Care for Your Teeth</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.ada.org/en/science-research/ada-seal-of-acceptance\">https://www.ada.org/en/science-research/ada-seal-of-acceptance</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/health/conditionsandtreatments/dental-erosion\">https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/health/conditionsandtreatments/dental-erosion</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda#_ref-12\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer
